k𝑘k client index k𝑘k where k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}
𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} k𝑘k-th client’s local data
𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} Total Data samples amongst clients
{𝐱i,d(k),yi(k)}superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑑𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘\{\mathbf{x}_{i,d}^{(k)},y_{i}^{(k)}\} The input and the accompanying class-labeled output
𝑾rsubscript𝑾𝑟{{\bm{W}}}_{r} The parameters of the global model at r𝑟r-th round
Fr​(𝑾)subscript𝐹𝑟𝑾F_{r}({{\bm{W}}}) The loss function of the global model at r𝑟r-th round
fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} The local loss function for each data sample i𝑖i
𝑾ksubscript𝑾𝑘{\bm{W}}_{k} The model parameters of the k𝑘k-th client
𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} Number of updates performed locally to update the model
η𝜂\eta Learning rate
E𝐸E Number of epochs
b𝑏b Batch size
Tkc​m​psubscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑐𝑚𝑝𝑘T^{cmp}_{k} Local computation time of k𝑘k-th client
𝒯ksubscript𝒯𝑘\mathcal{T}_{k} Number of local updates
Tt​o​tsuperscript𝑇𝑡𝑜𝑡T^{tot} The time budget for the whole training process
fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} The used CPU speed at k𝑘k-th client
ΦksubscriptΦ𝑘\Phi_{k} The required CPU cycles to process one local sample
Trsubscript𝑇𝑟T_{r} The round deadline determined by the server
Tktranssubscriptsuperscript𝑇trans𝑘T^{\mathrm{trans}}_{k} The upload time (i.e., uploading latency)
rkrsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑟r_{k}^{r} Transmit data rate achieved by the k𝑘k-th client

references: As Fig. 1 depicts, this work considers a set of 𝒦={1,…,K}𝒦1…𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{1,\dots,K\} heterogeneous edge devices, K=|𝒦|𝐾𝒦K=|\mathcal{K}|, associated with and coordinated by an edge server via a base station (BS). Each individual k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} device owns a local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}, with Dk=|𝒟k|subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘D_{k}=|\mathcal{D}_{k}| number of samples, and the total number of samples amongst all devices is D=∑k=1KDk𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘D=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{D_{k}}. Each local dataset, 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}, comprises a number of sample data with input-output pairings as follows: {𝐱i,d(k),yi(k)}i=1Dksubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑑𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘𝑖1\{\mathbf{x}_{i,d}^{(k)},y_{i}^{(k)}\}^{D_{k}}_{i=1}, where 𝐱i,d(k)∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑑𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}_{i,d}^{(k)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is an input with d𝑑d features, and yi(k)∈ℝsuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘ℝy_{i}^{(k)}\in\mathbb{R} is the accompanying class-labeled output. Each device behaves differently based on its activities, generating different sizes of local data; thus, 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} is non-i.i.d. and unbalanced. As previously stated, the connections between the devices and the server are made via an unreliable wireless link. Also, the devices themselves are resource-constrained, posing the challenge of scheduling and selecting participants in order to improve the convergence speed and minimize training time, particularly for CFL, where the main objective is to train a set of models rather than a single model as in conventional training. For the reader’s convenience, the main symbols utilized in this work are listed in Table I.

S7.T2.caption: TABLE II: Simulation parameters
S7.T2.table:
Sym. Parameter Value(s)
K𝐾K # of participating devices (20, 50, 100, 200)
R𝑅R # of training rounds 200 for FEMNIST and 500 for CIFAR-10
E𝐸E # of local training epochs 10
b𝑏b Batch size 32
η𝜂\eta Learning rate 0.01, 0.009
B𝐵B Bandwidth 10 MHz
Pm​i​nsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑖𝑛P_{min} Minimum transmission power -10 dBm
Pm​a​xsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑎𝑥P_{max} Maximum transmission power 20 dBm
N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} Background noise -10 dBm
Pkm​i​nsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑚𝑖𝑛P_{k}^{min} Minimum CPU frequency 1 GHz
Pkm​a​xsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑚𝑎𝑥P_{k}^{max} Maximum CPU frequency 9 GHz
references: In all experiments, we use a bandwidth of B=10𝐵10B=10 MHz, with each sub-channel having a bandwidth of 111 MHz. The channel gain of each device, hrksubscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑘𝑟h^{k}_{r}, is randomly modeled with a path loss (α=g0​(d0d)4𝛼subscript𝑔0superscriptsubscript𝑑0𝑑4\alpha=g_{0}(\frac{d_{0}}{d})^{4}) , where g0=−35subscript𝑔035g_{0}=-35 dB and the baseline distance d0=2subscript𝑑02d_{0}=2 m. We assume that the distances between the devices and the coordinating server are uniformly distributed between 202020 and 100100100 m. In addition, the power of AWGN is defined as N0=10−6subscript𝑁0superscript106N_{0}=10^{-6}watts. The transmission power Prksubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑘𝑟P^{k}_{r} is distributed at random between pm​i​n=−10subscript𝑝𝑚𝑖𝑛10p_{min}=-10 dBm and pm​a​x=20subscript𝑝𝑚𝑎𝑥20p_{max}=20 dBm. The device’s CPU frequency fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} is generated randomly between 111 GHz and 999 GHz, and the required CPU cycles per data point, ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, is set to 202020 and it is assumed to be homogeneous for all devices. We use two federated datasets, FEMNIST and CIFAR-10 [45], for handwriting classification and object recognition, respectively. Specifically, FEMNIST is utilized for handwriting classifications of both letters and digits (A-Z, a-z, and 0-9), and it has 305,654, 28 x 28, images while CIFAR-10 consists of 60,000 32x32 colored images. We split both datasets for each device into 80% for training and 2% for testing. Further, we utilize both datasets in a non-i.i.d. manner, whereas we split each dataset into ℐℐ\mathcal{I} fragments, and then we assign each device only two random classes. For the model architecture, the convolutional neural network (CNN) classifier is adopted for FEMNIST, and Alexnet—a deep neural network (DNN) is adopted for CIFAR-10. In our models, we employed 2 hidden layers in the FEMNIST model and 13 hidden layers in the CIFAR-10 model. For both learning tasks, we utilized the ReLU activation function for the hidden layers and the Softmax activation function for the output layer. To simplify the presentation, we list all simulation parameters in Table II.

references:
Now, we present the results of the testing accuracy, focusing on the fairness between clients.
We note that the training procedure for both all the algorithms, the proposed and benchmarks, has produced multiple models based on clustering, including a conventional FEEL model and a more tailored model for every group, as depicted in Table III. We test all models amongst 151515 clients after finishing all the training rounds to show the effectiveness of each model depending on the resulting accuracy. One can see that our proposed approach yields three better-tailored models. As shown in Table III(a), it is clear that all participating devices attain well-fitting accuracy (outlined in green color), and inconsistency in performance (maximum accuracy and minimum accuracy in the last row of Table III(a)) across all
is approximately 10%percent1010\% only when our approach is used. In comparison, as depicted in Table III(b), almost more than 1313\frac{1}{3} of the tested participants(i.e., P 1, P 2, P 3, P 4, and P 5) achieve undesired accuracy (outlined in red color). The inconsistency in performance can reach up to 31.4%percent31.431.4\%, demonstrating that some resulted models are still biased to the repeatedly selected devices which dominate the clustering.

S7.T3.st1.table:

references:
The study of FL deployment via edge networks from various perspectives has gained a lot of interest in the literature.
A decentralized stochastic gradient descent approach was studied in [31] considering the context of a bandwidth limit in several channel conditions, where every client is chosen opportunistically for transmission according to its channel state.
Earlier works considered perfect updates-upload tasks to address the delay aspects’ challenges in FEEL. Yet, the impacts of wireless channels are ignored, especially the ability to leverage the characteristics of the channels (e.g., fading, multi-access, and broadcasting) to reduce the latency. Therefore, the broadband analogue aggregation technique is fine-tuned for probabilistic channels due to restricted radio spectrum, particularly channel capacity [31].
To be more precise, prior to transmitting the models, the edge devices assess the sparsity of the gradients and then transfer them to a lower-dimensional realm constrained by the limited channel capacity. In addition, the works in [32] investigated the convergence of the FL algorithm across wireless links, taking into account the effect of unstable connections on the global model convergence.

As Fig. 1 depicts, this work considers a set of 𝒦={1,…,K}𝒦1…𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{1,\dots,K\} heterogeneous edge devices, K=|𝒦|𝐾𝒦K=|\mathcal{K}|, associated with and coordinated by an edge server via a base station (BS). Each individual k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} device owns a local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}, with Dk=|𝒟k|subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘D_{k}=|\mathcal{D}_{k}| number of samples, and the total number of samples amongst all devices is D=∑k=1KDk𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘D=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{D_{k}}. Each local dataset, 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}, comprises a number of sample data with input-output pairings as follows: {𝐱i,d(k),yi(k)}i=1Dksubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑑𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘𝑖1\{\mathbf{x}_{i,d}^{(k)},y_{i}^{(k)}\}^{D_{k}}_{i=1}, where 𝐱i,d(k)∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑑𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}_{i,d}^{(k)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is an input with d𝑑d features, and yi(k)∈ℝsuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘ℝy_{i}^{(k)}\in\mathbb{R} is the accompanying class-labeled output. Each device behaves differently based on its activities, generating different sizes of local data; thus, 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} is non-i.i.d. and unbalanced. As previously stated, the connections between the devices and the server are made via an unreliable wireless link. Also, the devices themselves are resource-constrained, posing the challenge of scheduling and selecting participants in order to improve the convergence speed and minimize training time, particularly for CFL, where the main objective is to train a set of models rather than a single model as in conventional training. For the reader’s convenience, the main symbols utilized in this work are listed in Table I.

It is worth highlighting that the server is anticipated to have considerably more computing capabilities than the clients; therefore, the computation cost on the server side is negligible.
We can see that there is a trade-off in the scheduling problem between the number of participants chosen in a given round and the entire number of rounds, which could be handled by Trsubscript𝑇𝑟T_{r}. Assuming we started with a short Trsubscript𝑇𝑟T_{r}, the number of engaging participants in ΩrsubscriptΩ𝑟\Omega_{r} can decrease, which is unsuitable for CFL leading to slowly partitioning the clients into congruent groups. This brings out unwanted communication costs due to increasing the number of training rounds needed to converge. Hence, we propose to initiate a long Trsubscript𝑇𝑟T_{r} at the beginning of the training; then, this time is reduced as the correct clustering is performed where only the best clients that require less latency will be selected from the cluster reaching the stopping point as follows:

In all experiments, we use a bandwidth of B=10𝐵10B=10 MHz, with each sub-channel having a bandwidth of 111 MHz. The channel gain of each device, hrksubscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑘𝑟h^{k}_{r}, is randomly modeled with a path loss (α=g0​(d0d)4𝛼subscript𝑔0superscriptsubscript𝑑0𝑑4\alpha=g_{0}(\frac{d_{0}}{d})^{4}) , where g0=−35subscript𝑔035g_{0}=-35 dB and the baseline distance d0=2subscript𝑑02d_{0}=2 m. We assume that the distances between the devices and the coordinating server are uniformly distributed between 202020 and 100100100 m. In addition, the power of AWGN is defined as N0=10−6subscript𝑁0superscript106N_{0}=10^{-6}watts. The transmission power Prksubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑘𝑟P^{k}_{r} is distributed at random between pm​i​n=−10subscript𝑝𝑚𝑖𝑛10p_{min}=-10 dBm and pm​a​x=20subscript𝑝𝑚𝑎𝑥20p_{max}=20 dBm. The device’s CPU frequency fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} is generated randomly between 111 GHz and 999 GHz, and the required CPU cycles per data point, ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, is set to 202020 and it is assumed to be homogeneous for all devices. We use two federated datasets, FEMNIST and CIFAR-10 [45], for handwriting classification and object recognition, respectively. Specifically, FEMNIST is utilized for handwriting classifications of both letters and digits (A-Z, a-z, and 0-9), and it has 305,654, 28 x 28, images while CIFAR-10 consists of 60,000 32x32 colored images. We split both datasets for each device into 80% for training and 2% for testing. Further, we utilize both datasets in a non-i.i.d. manner, whereas we split each dataset into ℐℐ\mathcal{I} fragments, and then we assign each device only two random classes. For the model architecture, the convolutional neural network (CNN) classifier is adopted for FEMNIST, and Alexnet—a deep neural network (DNN) is adopted for CIFAR-10. In our models, we employed 2 hidden layers in the FEMNIST model and 13 hidden layers in the CIFAR-10 model. For both learning tasks, we utilized the ReLU activation function for the hidden layers and the Softmax activation function for the output layer. To simplify the presentation, we list all simulation parameters in Table II.

Maximum number of data points: In this algorithm, the coordinating server chooses the participants having the largest data sizes and keeps connecting with them until the end of the training. We also extend this approach to select the maximum number of data examples amongst clients every round, assuming that the channel of each participant is not stable and diverse participants may be involved in different rounds.

Now, we present the results of the testing accuracy, focusing on the fairness between clients.
We note that the training procedure for both all the algorithms, the proposed and benchmarks, has produced multiple models based on clustering, including a conventional FEEL model and a more tailored model for every group, as depicted in Table III. We test all models amongst 151515 clients after finishing all the training rounds to show the effectiveness of each model depending on the resulting accuracy. One can see that our proposed approach yields three better-tailored models. As shown in Table III(a), it is clear that all participating devices attain well-fitting accuracy (outlined in green color), and inconsistency in performance (maximum accuracy and minimum accuracy in the last row of Table III(a)) across all
is approximately 10%percent1010\% only when our approach is used. In comparison, as depicted in Table III(b), almost more than 1313\frac{1}{3} of the tested participants(i.e., P 1, P 2, P 3, P 4, and P 5) achieve undesired accuracy (outlined in red color). The inconsistency in performance can reach up to 31.4%percent31.431.4\%, demonstrating that some resulted models are still biased to the repeatedly selected devices which dominate the clustering.

Furthermore, to validate the proposed algorithms, we perform other simulation experiments using the CIFAR-10 dataset as a complex learning task under non-i.i.d. federated settings. This assists in generalizing the performance of the proposed algorithms for different application domains. Figs. 5(a), 5(b), 5(c) and 5(d) show the minimum, maximum, and average testing accuracy amongst clients where the minimum accuracy represents the lowest accuracy can be achieved by the client and vise versa. It is worth mentioning that the proposed approach balances the accuracy between all clients despite the number of participating clients where the gap between the maximum and minimum accuracy amongst clients reaches up to 10%percent1010\%, meaning that the resulting models optimally fit all local data distribution. At the same time, we notice that the best channel, the best l2-norm, and the max-samples approaches increase the accuracy gap between the clients, reaching up to 70%percent7070\%, especially if the number of clients increases. This stems from the fact that the server stays connected with the same clients during all global rounds in those approaches, particularly when the channel is not changing rapidly, leading to biased models that can only fit the participants’ clients. In addition, random scheduling provides less accuracy gaps due to the randomness of participant selection. Nevertheless, the proposed scheduling approach substantially outperforms all benchmarks and provides much more stable accuracy regardless of the distribution of the data and the number of clients in the network.

The transmission power Prksubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑘𝑟P^{k}_{r} is distributed at random between pm​i​n=−10subscript𝑝𝑚𝑖𝑛10p_{min}=-10 dBm and pm​a​x=20subscript𝑝𝑚𝑎𝑥20p_{max}=20 dBm. The device’s CPU frequency fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} is generated randomly between 111 GHz and 999 GHz, and the required CPU cycles per data point, ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, is set to 202020 and it is assumed to be homogeneous for all devices. We use two federated datasets, FEMNIST and CIFAR-10 [45], for handwriting classification and object recognition, respectively. Specifically, FEMNIST is utilized for handwriting classifications of both letters and digits (A-Z, a-z, and 0-9), and it has 305,654, 28 x 28, images while CIFAR-10 consists of 60,000 32x32 colored images. We split both datasets for each device into 80% for training and 2% for testing. Further, we utilize both datasets in a non-i.i.d. manner, whereas we split each dataset into ℐℐ\mathcal{I} fragments, and then we assign each device only two random classes. For the model architecture, the convolutional neural network (CNN) classifier is adopted for FEMNIST, and Alexnet—a deep neural network (DNN) is adopted for CIFAR-10. In our models, we employed 2 hidden layers in the FEMNIST model and 13 hidden layers in the CIFAR-10 model. For both learning tasks, we utilized the ReLU activation function for the hidden layers and the Softmax activation function for the output layer. To simplify the presentation, we list all simulation parameters in Table II.

Maximum number of data points: In this algorithm, the coordinating server chooses the participants having the largest data sizes and keeps connecting with them until the end of the training. We also extend this approach to select the maximum number of data examples amongst clients every round, assuming that the channel of each participant is not stable and diverse participants may be involved in different rounds.

Now, we present the results of the testing accuracy, focusing on the fairness between clients.
We note that the training procedure for both all the algorithms, the proposed and benchmarks, has produced multiple models based on clustering, including a conventional FEEL model and a more tailored model for every group, as depicted in Table III. We test all models amongst 151515 clients after finishing all the training rounds to show the effectiveness of each model depending on the resulting accuracy. One can see that our proposed approach yields three better-tailored models. As shown in Table III(a), it is clear that all participating devices attain well-fitting accuracy (outlined in green color), and inconsistency in performance (maximum accuracy and minimum accuracy in the last row of Table III(a)) across all
is approximately 10%percent1010\% only when our approach is used. In comparison, as depicted in Table III(b), almost more than 1313\frac{1}{3} of the tested participants(i.e., P 1, P 2, P 3, P 4, and P 5) achieve undesired accuracy (outlined in red color). The inconsistency in performance can reach up to 31.4%percent31.431.4\%, demonstrating that some resulted models are still biased to the repeatedly selected devices which dominate the clustering.

Furthermore, to validate the proposed algorithms, we perform other simulation experiments using the CIFAR-10 dataset as a complex learning task under non-i.i.d. federated settings. This assists in generalizing the performance of the proposed algorithms for different application domains. Figs. 5(a), 5(b), 5(c) and 5(d) show the minimum, maximum, and average testing accuracy amongst clients where the minimum accuracy represents the lowest accuracy can be achieved by the client and vise versa. It is worth mentioning that the proposed approach balances the accuracy between all clients despite the number of participating clients where the gap between the maximum and minimum accuracy amongst clients reaches up to 10%percent1010\%, meaning that the resulting models optimally fit all local data distribution. At the same time, we notice that the best channel, the best l2-norm, and the max-samples approaches increase the accuracy gap between the clients, reaching up to 70%percent7070\%, especially if the number of clients increases. This stems from the fact that the server stays connected with the same clients during all global rounds in those approaches, particularly when the channel is not changing rapidly, leading to biased models that can only fit the participants’ clients. In addition, random scheduling provides less accuracy gaps due to the randomness of participant selection. Nevertheless, the proposed scheduling approach substantially outperforms all benchmarks and provides much more stable accuracy regardless of the distribution of the data and the number of clients in the network.
